Dear Mr. McCree:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Two youth, Youth H and Youth I, got into a physical altercation
and staff did not intervene properly, resulting in one of the youth’s
losing consciousness.
Investigation The Complainant for the allegations provided was anonymous,
so no further information was able to be provided.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 07/30/2024 during
an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She confirmed
that there had not been youth named in the allegations placed at
the facility, and that there were not any other similar incidents
recently where youth fought to the point of losing consciousness.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed separately on 08/05/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to
the facility. Both Youth A and Youth B stated they had not heard
of the youth named in the allegations or heard of any similar
incident occurring recently.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed separately on 08/05/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to
the facility. They were both not familiar with any youth with those
names or a similar incident that had possibly occurred recently.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone on 09/25/2024. He
could not recall any similar incidents to the one alleged or any
youth placed at the program that could have been involved.
2

During a video conference on 08/20/2024 DHHS Worker 1
provided an update on his investigation and was not able to state
a final result at that time.
Documents reviewed:
• Incident reports were reviewed and there were none that
matched what occurred in the allegations.
• Names of discharged youth were reviewed, and none
matched the names provided in the allegations.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with youth
and staff and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that an incident as described in the allegations occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
Title books, records, and reports.
Rule Code & Public Act 116 722.120
Section (c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the department,
Description and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and household
members, to provide accurate and truthful information to the
department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The incident between Youth H and Youth I was captured on
camera and since that time the footage has been tampered with
by staff.
Investigation The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 07/30/2024 during
an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She confirmed
no similar incidents had occurred as described in the allegations.
In addition, she provided information on the facility security
camera system and its related security features. The Chief
Administrator stated staff would not have any ability to delete any
particular footage, as everything captured is automatically stored
and then automatically deleted after 30 days.
The facility Licensee Designee was interviewed over the phone
on 01/24/2025. He reported longstanding practice within the
facility that Supervisory staff and above are the only staff that
have access to security camera footage. He did not have any
concern that staff would have a way to log in to the security
3

camera system and view footage without the proper credentials.
Licensee Designee stated the software that the facility used for
this service did not allow for any tampering as it had many view
only settings and would only be deleted automatically after 30
days and not because of any staff’s actions.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interview with
administration. There was no evidence found that staff have the
ability to alter or delete video footage or did so in response to the
alleged incident.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Children that report abuse/neglect at the facility are transferred out
of the facility.
Investigation The Complainant for the allegations provided was anonymous,
so no further information was able to be provided.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone on
07/30/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She stated the design of the programming offered by the
facility did not offer the ability to “transfer out” youth from the
facility for any reason. Youth were placed and discharged at the
facility strictly based off of contractual agreements and court
ordered placements. She remarked that one current difficulty for
the facility was that there were youth placed within the facility that
have either reached maximum benefit or had successfully
completed the program but could not be discharged because of
difficulties in finding new appropriate placements.
4

Administrator 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He denied allegations
that youth were able to be discharged and moved from the
program for any reasons similar to the allegation. This was stated
because the facility has contracts for placements with the State of
Michigan as well as other case management organizations, and
those contracts contained “no eject, no reject” language that
prevented discharge of youth without court orders directing the
program to do so.
Documents reviewed:
• The facility’s program statement was reviewed and there
was no language within it referring to youth being
discharged for any other reason than court orders or
decisions by referrals sources providing case management.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with
administration and documentation reviewed. There was no
evidence found that the facility is able to discharge youth for any
reasons similar to what was listed in the allegations.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
Title required.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
Description assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff members are threatened to have CPS called on them or to
be written up when staff members threaten to report the concerns
at the facility.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated
that he has never felt any concern with reporting concerns up to
management or to external entities such as Centralized Intake that
were negative or needing addressing, and that he had never felt
like he faced repercussions as a result of speaking up.
5

Staff 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She felt that
she has never faced repercussions as a result of speaking up
about any issues in the facility, and did not feel that her personal
life would ever be used against her in any form within the
workplace.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 09/04/2024. She
recalled Administrator 2 as a staff member who would “pressure”
other staff if they expressed concerns about anything occurring
within the facility. Staff 3 did not report that actions that could be
interpreted as repercussions occurred as a result and could not
provide any more specific information than this.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone on 11/18/2024.
She reported that she has never felt concern that there could be
retribution that occurred caused by her reporting something up to
management above her or to Centralized Intake.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with staff,
there was no evidence found that staff have calls made to report
concerns of child abuse or neglect on their own personal families
as a result of any action they themselves took in the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (2) At a minimum, 1 direct care worker shall be responsible for not
Description more than 10 residents at 1 time during residents’ normal
awake hours and not more than 20 residents at 1 time during
the residents’ normal sleeping hours.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff members are left on a pod by themselves to supervise 6-7
residents independently.
Investigation Administrator 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He did not believe
there were any specific instances of staff being out of ratio while
supervising youth.
6

Youth A was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated
that staff are almost always in ratio but that there have been times
that he has not been allowed out of his room in the morning
because there was not ratio to meet the needed supervision of
youth. Youth A stated that he and the other youth on his pod
would have to stay in his room until staff told them there was
enough staff present to meet ratio, then they would be let out.
Youth A reported this happening as long as half the day on one
occasion and recalled that it had happened once or twice over the
summer.
Youth B was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth B did
not believe there were any times when staff were not within ratio
while supervising him at the facility. He then stated that there
were common occasions earlier in his placement when he had to
stay in his bedroom after wake-up time because there were not
enough staff to cover the pod. He believed that sometimes staff
would explain that as such and sometimes they would not when it
was occurring. He recalled the longest time frame for this
occurring was until 11:00am or so. Youth B could not recall any
specific times this occurred.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He reported
that he has not worked in any situations where staff were not able
to ensure ratio requirements were met for supervision of youth.
Staff 1 denied participating in or seeing any situations where youth
had to stay in their rooms past the normal wake up time.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 2 did
not believe there was ever a time that she was a part of ratio not
being met. She referenced common situations where staff would
cover other units even for short periods of time in order to meet
ratio. Staff 2 did not recall any times when youth had to stay in
their rooms after they were supposed to get up for the morning as
a result of not having enough staff to meet ratio.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 09/04/2024. She
stated that during her time employed at the facility there were
occasions when she was a part of supervising youth out of ratio,
but could not provide any more specifics. Staff 3 stated that she
was not aware of any times when youth were kept in their rooms
7

when they should have been able to leave them in the morning
after waking up.
Youth C was interviewed on 09/19/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth C reported common
occasions when he and other youth had to stay in their rooms
after wake up time in the morning. Youth C was told by staff that
this was sometimes caused by the facility not having enough staff
to meet the proper supervising ratio. Youth C could not identify
any specific staff related to this concern, or any dates that this
occurred. Youth C also recalled times when youth would be
allowed out of their rooms first thing in the morning, but because
of supervision and ratio issues they would have to sit in a
classroom and not move forward with their regular schedules for
the morning. Youth C also commented that it was common for
other youth to not want to come out of their rooms in the morning
anyway, regardless of any possible supervision issues.
Youth D was interviewed on 09/19/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth D stated that it was rare, but
that there were times that he had to stay in his room in the
morning until enough staff arrived to meet ratio. Youth D could
not provide any more detail on when this had occurred.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone on 09/25/2024. He did
not believe there were ever any times when there were not
enough staff to cover normal supervision ratios. Youth E denied
ever having to stay in his room in the mornings longer than
normally necessary.
Staff 4 and Staff 5 were interviewed separately over the phone on
10/18/2024. They denied ever experiencing times when they
were supervising youth and ratio was not met. They both also
denied ever having youth stay in their rooms in the mornings until
ratio can be met. Supervisor 1 noted that the common practice
was that youth were in their rooms until head count at 8:30 am.
He stated that the likelihood of not having enough staff was low
because shift change occurred at 7:30 am, allowing enough time
to pass before the youth to get up to take care of any staffing
issues.
Youth G was interviewed on 10/18/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He reported that about once a
month there is an occasion where staff tell the youth that ratio
cannot be met in the morning, and they have to stay in their rooms
until it can.
8

Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone on 11/18/2024.
She reported never seeing the allegations occur and described
the normal procedure of having to keep night shift staff over to
meet supervision ratios when necessary.
Documents reviewed:
• The facility’s Program Statement was provided and
reviewed. This documented the facility’s ratio
commitments, which during waking hours were one youth
to three staff for the cognitively impaired program and one
youth to five staff for the juvenile justice youth program.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with youth
and staff and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that youth to staff ratios for the supervision of youth were
not being met.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(i) Food or creating alternative menus.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff members take and eat the children's food.
Investigation Youth A and Youth B were interviewed separately on 08/05/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to
the facility. They both had similar responses in that they had
never witnessed any instances of staff taking food from youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
remarked that youth are not able to eat on their pods and that he
9

had never seen any instances where youth had their food taken
by staff for any reason.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She denied
ever seeing an instance of staff taking the youth’s food.
Youth C, Youth D and Youth E were interviewed separately on
09/19/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. All the youth reported never having seen staff take youth’s
food and none expressed concern over the possibility of this
occurring.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone on 09/25/2024. He
stated that he had never witnessed any staff taking food from
youth in any form.
Staff 4, Staff 5, and Supervisor 1 were interviewed separately
over the phone on 10/18/2024. They all denied ever seeing staff
take youth’s food for any reason.
Documents Reviewed:
• In email communication with the facility that occurred on
01/27/2025 it was confirmed that there was no facility policy
regarding food service or prohibiting staff taking food from
youth.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with youth
and staff. There was no evidence found that food had been taken
from youth by staff for any reason.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was provided regarding the requirement to
establish food service policies within behavior management policy
& procedures.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
10

(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references
to a youth's background or appearance or mental state.
Yelling, threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly
prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff yell at children, specifically those that are on the autism
spectrum.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated
that he was familiar with the specific pod within the program that
was designed to treat youth with cognitive limitations. Staff 1
stated he was not familiar with any instances where other staff
yelled at those youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated
that she has worked on the pod with cognitively limited youth and
has never yelled at the youth, nor has she witnessed other staff
doing the same.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 09/04/2024. She
stated that during her employment at the facility she recalled staff
members talking to youth in this specific pod as if they were not
people, but more like “animals or babies.” Staff 3 could not
provide any more specific information regarding this concern and
denied speaking to any youth at the facility in this manner herself.
Youth C, Youth D and Youth E were interviewed separately on
09/19/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. All youth reported that they have never been yelled at by
staff and have not witnessed any other youth receiving the same
treatment. Youth C recalled instances where staff appeared to be
getting frustrated while working with the youth and would call for
other staff to cover them so they could take a break.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone on 09/25/2024. He
denied ever being yelled at by staff or witnessing this occurring to
any other youth.
11

Staff 4, Staff 5, and Supervisor 1 were interviewed over the
phone on 10/18/2024. They individually reported never having
witnessed any staff yelling at any youth at the facility, and denied
ever doing so themselves.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone on 11/18/2024.
She stated that she has never yelled at any of the youth in the
facility and has never witnessed any other staff doing the same.
Documents Reviewed:
• Facility behavior management policies & procedures were
provided and reviewed. This policy stated that “the use of
verbal and non-physical crisis intervention communication
intervention techniques will de-escalate the youth and
prevent the need for physical intervention. These
communication techniques include listening, supportive
communication, problem solving counseling, and conflict
resolution counseling.”
• Facility verbal de-escalation training materials were
provided and reviewed. This training material outlined how
staff are trained on the belief that “all people have the right
to be treated with dignity and respect.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with youth
and staff. There was no evidence found that staff have yelled at
any youth in the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities; seclusion
Title plan; prohibitions; reduction and elimination.
Rule Code & R 400.4162
Section (11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Interviews with youth provided for this investigation alleged that
the use of seclusion was not performed properly.
Investigation Interviews provided for this investigation by Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, Youth D and Youth G all provided separate and
consistent accounts of having to stay in their bedrooms at the time
12

of normal wake up hours. This occurred for varying time lengths
and on multiple occasions staff members informed youth that they
had to stay in their rooms because there were concerns about
meeting the ratio needed for proper supervision of the youth.
Documentation reviewed:
• The facility received an approved variance most recently as
of 11/27/2024 regarding the use of seclusion as an
intervention. In the approval for this variance, it is stated
that “staff must only use seclusion as a temporary response
to prevent life-threatening injury or serious bodily harm
when other interventions are ineffective.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per interviews with
youth and staff and documentation reviewed. Evidence was found
that the facility was utilizing seclusions in a non-approved manner
by keeping youth in their bedrooms past the normal wake up time
due to staffing issues.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
• SIR #2025SIC0000004 dated 12/17/2024, CAP approved
01/24/2025
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
